subject: Information
description_text:
Hello, you're not being entirely honest. I ordered an item from you,
you confirmed the order, and then you sent me an email saying you were
canceling the order and changing the price. I'm going to ask Amazon to
take legal action because what you did is illegal.

conversations.body_text:
Just a quick reminder of the law: the price displayed is the price
sold, so I'm claiming the item you debited from my account.


Le ven. 5 déc. 2025, 5 h 21 a.m., General and sales enquiries <
service@simsonn.com> a écrit :

> Due to a pricing error made by our colleagues after the Black Friday
> event, orders with incorrect pricing were cancelled. We have now corrected
> this error, and you can repurchase if needed.
>
> ------------------------------
> service@simsonn.com
>
>
> *

Oui, le prix affiché doit être le prix vendu, surtout au Québec avec la
Politique d'exactitude des prix : si le prix à la caisse est plus élevé, le
commerçant doit vous vendre l'article au prix le plus bas (celui affiché)
et vous offrir un dédommagement (gratuit si le prix est
10\(oumoins,rabaisde10\) si plus élevé), sauf exceptions comme les
commerces qui ne font pas d'étiquetage individuel. C'est une obligation
légale, même en cas d'erreur ou de publicité.

Yes, generally, online displayed prices must be respected as they form an
offer, especially in places like Quebec where laws mandate price accuracy,
requiring merchants to honor the lower price if it differs from the scanned
price, often with compensation like getting the item free (under $10) or a
discount (over $10) under Canada's voluntary Scanner Price Accuracy Code,
though terms & conditions and jurisdiction matter.
